messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:44): oh that's hilarious
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:44): http://blog.kansai.com/kasutera7966/132
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:45): it has two occurances of <ruby> ... <rt> ... </ruby>, which is fine as far as that goes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:45): but then at the end of the main bit of text there are two orphan </rt> tags
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:45): clearly some software somewhere was like "ok well i'm closing these damnit!"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:49): that's some interesting markup right there :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:51): so uh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:51): how do you get IE to actually render hte ruby
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:53): <!doctype html> <ruby> test <rt> test </rbuy>
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:53): wfm
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:54): though you probably want </ruby> there :)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:55): uses IE6
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:56): I don't think IE does "advanced" ruby
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:56): the rbc and rtc elements
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:57): s/advanced/complex/
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:57): http://jyosui.blogzine.jp/blog/cat7074652/index.html
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:57): ^ are you sure you want us to support ruby?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:58): woah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:58): it only works in quirks mode for me
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:00): <ruby><rb>„Éè„ÇØ„Éä„Éª„Éû„Çø„Çø</rb><rt>„Åè„Çà„Åè„Çà„Åô„Çã„Å™</rp></ruby>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:01): good work matching tags there http://d.hatena.ne.jp/keyword/%A5%E9%A5%A4%A5%AA%A5%F3%A1%A6%A5%AD%A5%F3%A5%B0
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:01): afaict IE ignores <rp> and <rb>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:02): yes
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:02): and <rt> only functions if it has a non-whitespace previous sibling
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:03): ok so here is what i propose:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:03): <ruby> and </ruby> act like any random phrasing element tags
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:04): <rp> and <rt> pop elements up to the nearest in-scope <ruby>, if any
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:04): </rp> and </rt> act like normal phrasing element end tags
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:04): <ruby> represents a run of one or more ruby annotations
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:05): each annotation consists of some phrasing content followed by an <rt> element or a run of <rp>-<rt>-<rp> elements
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:05): <rp> elements get ignored altogether
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:06): the renderer takes all content of the <ruby> element and splits it into groups of  not-rt, rt
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:06): for each of those groups it renders the not-rt as the base and the rt as the ruby text
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:07): notes this in the spec for tomorrow
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:07): </ruby> should close <rp> / <rt>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:08): it would, if treated as i described above
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:08): without error?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:08): oh you don't want it to be an error?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:08): sure, we can add that
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:08): cool
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:08): likes lazy markup
99d799105c5630cb16b3a7b54e6ae26e (14:10): http://tinyurl.com/6b7s4w (babelfish'd from ja to en) mentions that ie8's ruby support.. wonder how that'll be done..

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:14): you can suggest a better translation :-)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:18): i'll fill in the details tomorrow
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:19): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: i don't envy you your job
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:20): you referring to my survey mail, I guess
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:21): yeah

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:22): if you do have people leave the group because of the quorum thing, please let me know so i can invite them to send feedback through the whatwg -- i imagine there might well be people who want to send feedback but don't care about the voting nonsense
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:22): (me, for instance)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:23): I think at least a couple of those people who have not responded are not actually interested in the HTML work
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:23): or maybe just interested in the parts of it that relate to forms
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:24): I'd wonder whether they would have plans to ever send feedback and have a discussion about that even

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:26): but yeah, if they do decide to leave, I will let you know, and will myself point out to them that the whatwg list is a great place for them to submit any feedback they might have
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:26): hmm, <rt> closes <rp>, but <rp> does not close <rt>
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:27): </ruby> closes <rt><rp>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:27): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: yeah, IE's handling is seriously borked
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:28): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: cool
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:28): what's our current quorum level?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:28): we are short one response
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:29): ah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:29): ChrisW told me on Friday that he would respond by the deadline, but he didn't (he's traveling and I would guess he may have been without connectivity)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:29): wow, no negative votes at all
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:29): impressive
